unnormalised: Okay, so you're thinking about a loan? That's cool, lots of us do! Whether it's for that dream home in Mumbai, a shiny new car, or maybe even to finally start that business you've always envisioned, loans are often the key. But understanding the whole loan process in India can feel like navigating a crowded local train – a bit overwhelming at first.
normalised: Okay, so you are thinking about a loan? That is cool, lots of us do! Whether it is for that dream home in Mumbai, a shiny new car, or maybe even to finally start that business you have always envisioned, loans are often the key. But understanding the whole loan process in India can feel like navigating a crowded local train - a bit overwhelming at first.

unnormalised: Let's break it down, shall we? First off, there are different types of loans. A home loan from HDFC or SBI could get you closer to owning that apartment, usually available up to 80% of the property value. A personal loan, on the other hand, offered by most banks (like ICICI) can be used for almost anything, from a wedding to medical expenses. Then there are education loans to fund degrees from places like IIT or IIM, with interest rates varying depending on the bank and the course. Don’t forget about vehicle loans; you can probably get a loan for up to 85% of the on-road price.
normalised: Let us break it down, shall we? First off, there are different types of loans. A home loan from H-D-F-C or S-B-I could get you closer to owning that apartment, usually available up to eighty percent of the property value. A personal loan, on the other hand, offered by most banks (like I-C-I-C-I) can be used for almost anything, from a wedding to medical expenses. Then there are education loans to fund degrees from places like I-I-T or I-I-M, with interest rates varying depending on the bank and the course. Do not forget about vehicle loans; you can probably get a loan for up to eighty five percent of the on-road price.

unnormalised: Now, about that pesky interest rate. It's expressed as a percentage, p.a. (per annum). So, if a loan agreement states 9.5% p.a., that’s the yearly interest you’ll pay. Interest can be fixed (stays the same throughout the loan) or floating (changes based on market conditions). Floating rates are often linked to benchmarks like the RBI repo rate. Keep an eye on that RBI rate announcements!
normalised: Now, about that pesky interest rate. It is expressed as a percentage, p.a. (per annum). So, if a loan agreement states nine point five percent p.a., that is the yearly interest you will pay. Interest can be fixed (stays the same throughout the loan) or floating (changes based on market conditions). Floating rates are often linked to benchmarks like the R-B-I repo rate. Keep an eye on that R-B-I rate announcements!

unnormalised: CIBIL score – this is your credit score, and it's crucial! A score of 750+ (out of 900) usually means you're a good borrower. Banks check this before approving your loan. Pay your credit card bills and EMIs on time, bhai! Otherwise, that score will plummet faster than you can say "loan rejection."
normalised: C-I-B-I-L score - this is your credit score, and it is crucial! A score of seven hundred and fifty plus (out of nine hundred) usually means you are a good borrower. Banks check this before approving your loan. Pay your credit card bills and E-M-I-s on time, bhai! Otherwise, that score will plummet faster than you can say "loan rejection."

unnormalised: Documentation is another hurdle. Banks usually require ID proof (Aadhaar card no. 1234-5678-9012 will do), address proof (like a utility bill), income proof (salary slips, ITR), and bank statements for the last 3 months at least. Keep those documents handy and updated; trust me, it will save you a lot of prep time.
normalised: Documentation is another hurdle. Banks usually require I-D proof (Aadhaar card number one two three four - five six seven eight - nine zero one two will do), address proof (like a utility bill), income proof (salary slips, I-T-R), and bank statements for the last three months at least. Keep those documents handy and updated; trust me, it will save you a lot of prep time.

unnormalised: EMIs (Equated Monthly Installments) are how you'll repay the loan. It's a fixed amount you pay each month until the loan is cleared. There are online EMI calculators that can help you figure out how much you'll be paying each month based on the loan amount, interest rate, and tenure. You can find them on most bank websites.
normalised: E-M-I-s (Equated Monthly Installments) are how you will repay the loan. It is a fixed amount you pay each month until the loan is cleared. There are online E-M-I calculators that can help you figure out how much you will be paying each month based on the loan amount, interest rate, and tenure. You can find them on most bank websites.

unnormalised: Loans can be a great tool, but handle them responsibly! Do your research, compare interest rates across different banks, understand the terms and conditions, and make sure you can comfortably afford the EMIs. Happy borrowing!
